title: 109_s2186
content: The "Commission to Strengthen Confidence in Congress Act of 2006" establishes a commission in the legislative branch with the purpose of enhancing confidence in Congress. The Commission established by the "Commission to Strengthen Confidence in Congress Act of 2006" aims to evaluate and report on congressional ethics requirements, official travel standards, gifts given to Members of Congress, disclosure laws, and the ban on certain activities. The Commission established by the "Commission to Strengthen Confidence in Congress Act of 2006" will assess and report on the effectiveness of the ban on Members of Congress and staff from lobbying their former office, make recommendations for altering the time frame, improve the process for earmarking priorities in appropriations Acts, evaluate public and privately funded travel by Members of Congress and staff, and investigate findings for reform. SEC. 4. COMPOSITION OF COMMISSION. The Commission shall consist of 10 members, including a chair and vice chair selected by leaders from both parties in the House and Senate. Additional members will be appointed by senior members of the Republican and Democratic parties in both chambers, with some being former members of Congress. The Commission consists of 10 members appointed by leaders from both parties in the House and Senate. Five members must be Democrats and 5 Republicans, with appointees not being government officials. Members should be prominent US citizens with experience in government-related professions. The Commission consists of 10 members appointed by leaders from both parties in the House and Senate, with appointees not being government officials. Members should be prominent US citizens with experience in government-related professions. All members must be appointed within 3 months of the enactment of the Act, and the Commission shall meet as soon as practicable. After the initial meeting, the Commission will meet upon the call of the chairman or a majority of its members, with 6 members constituting a quorum. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission's functions include submitting a report to Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations, proposing organization and procedures related to ethical safeguards in Congress. The Commission also has the power to recommend reforms and strengthen ethical safeguards. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and require witnesses to testify and produce documents through subpoenas issued by agreement of the chair and vice chair or by the affirmative vote of 6 members. The Commission can issue subpoenas with the agreement of the chair and vice chair or by a vote of 6 members. Subpoenas can be signed by the chairman or designated member and served by a designated person. Federal agencies must provide necessary information upon request by the Commission. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION. Members of the Commission do not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits, except for travel expenses and per diem. The Chair appoints a staff director who is compensated at a specified rate. The Commission appoints additional personnel as needed, without following standard civil service laws for appointments and pay rates. The staff director can also hire temporary services with Commission approval. The Architect of the Capitol provides office space and necessary equipment for the Commission on a nonreimbursable basis. Administrative support services are also provided by the Architect of the Capitol and the Administrator of General Services upon request. The Commission may receive additional support from US departments and agencies, including services, funds, facilities, staff, and other support services as authorized by law. The Commission can use the US mails and printing services as if it were a federal agency or a committee of Congress for printing and binding costs. SEC. 8. Security clearances for Commission members and staff will be provided by Federal agencies to access classified information. SEC. 9. Commission reports and termination. The Commission is required to submit annual reports to Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. They must also be available to testify and disseminate the reports to appropriate parties. The Commission will terminate once a majority agrees on the final report. The Commission will submit a final report to Congress when its purpose is fulfilled, and it will terminate along with all its authorities 60 days after submitting the report. SEC. 10. FUNDING. Authorized necessary sums for Act implementation.
